Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Situation2: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Story: My phone buzzes with a reminder: “Call Mom and Dad.” It’s Sunday evening, our weekly check-in. I know they wait for my call, eager to hear about my week, wanting to feel included in my life. I promised I’d always keep them updated, especially after moving out. But tonight, as I glance across the room, I see my boyfriend slumped on the couch, eyes red, shoulders tense. He just got off a call with his boss—another project rejected. He hasn’t said much, but I can feel the heaviness in the air. I want to sit beside him, hold his hand, let him know I’m here, that he’s not alone in this. But my phone keeps buzzing, and I imagine my parents waiting, maybe worrying if I don’t call on time. My heart pulls in two directions—toward the family that raised me and the person I love. I stand in the hallway, phone in hand, torn between comforting him and keeping my promise to them, wishing I could be in two places at once.
